thread.title: Royals take game 5 of ALDS 7-2, will face Blue Jays in ALCS
thread.title_full: Royals take game 5 of ALDS 7-2, will face Blue Jays in ALCS

author: DeAnn Smith
title: Royals take game 5 of ALDS 7-2, will face Blue Jays in ALCS
text:
Royals take game 5 of ALDS 7-2, will face Blue Jays in ALCS - KCTV5 Member Center: Royals take game 5 of ALDS 7-2, will face Blue Jays in ALCS Posted: deann.smith@kctv5.com Royals pitcher Johnny Cueto throwing early in Game 5 of the ALDS against the Astros (AP) Kansas City Royals' Alex Gordon, center, and Salvador Perez, left, celebrate in front of Houston Astros pitcher Mike Fiers, right, after scoring on a double by teammate Alex Rios during the fifth inning of Game 5 (AP) Kansas City Royals' Alex Rios, left, gets a hug from teammate Kendrys Morales after scoring on a sacrifice fly by Ben Zobrist during the fifth inning of Game 5 in baseball's American League Division Series against the Houston Astros, Wednesday (AP Photo) KANSAS CITY, MO (KCTV) - 
The Kansas City Royals beat the Houston Astros 7-2 in game 5 of the ALDS. They will face the Blue Jays on Friday in the ALCS. 
Royals pitcher Johnny Cueto has been throwing fire, but he also gave up a two-run home run. 
Luis Valbuena hit the home run in the second inning. Evan Gattis had managed to get on base after first baseman Eric Hosmer couldn't field a throw. He wasn't charged with an error. 
Center fielder Lorenzo Cain scored in the bottom of the fourth on a Hosmer single. Cain kept running after he rounded second like the cheetah he says he is when he saw the Astros didn't handle the hit cleanly. 
In the 5th, Alex Rios hit a double to left field and Royals took the lead 3-2. Next up Ben Zobrist hit a fly out, but left enough time for Rios to run across home plate, extending the Royals' lead. 
In the 8th, the Royals extended their lead when Kendrys Morales homered on a line drive to center field, bringing in Alcides Escobar and Lorenzo Cain. 
The Royals are asking Cueto to fulfill the role of shutdown ace in a deciding game they envisioned after they traded away three top prospects for him before this year's non-waiver trade deadline. However, the former Reds pitcher is 0-2 with a 5.52 ERA in four career playoff starts and didn't exactly carry Kansas City into the postseason after the deal with Cincinnati was made. 
Manager Ned Yost said during the game that he was pleased with how Cueto is throwing, and he's been throwing fire. 
The Royals are expected to pull Cueto at the first sign of serious trouble. The bullpen is well stocked and waiting. 
Refresh this page for updates.
